Title: Rich Man, Poor Man: Book 1

reviewText: In the 1970, it was the age of the mini series, two years before Roots, ABC network took a risk...their second novel for television. The first wasQB VII. Rich man was twelve chapters of television history  that is so good, it could be rerun today and not seem datedRich Man Poor Man (book one) is a story of two brothers,  Rudy (Peter Strauss) and Tom (Nick Nolte). Think Cain and Abel in a modern day setting, Rudy, the good son, strives for wealth and power. Tom, a fighter who lived the seedy side of life and grows into a strong man. Between both of them is Julie (Susan Blakely), who knows both men.The father of the boys (Edward Asner) is a strict hard working man, who owns a Bakery...He is easy on Rudy\ harder on Tom. The mini series took the Jordache family deom the late 1940 to the 1970s.Book one is laiden with cameo roles from such actors as  Steve Allen, Robert Reed, Van Johnson, William Smith (who will surface as the villian in book two), Bill Bixby and  Kay LenzWith success of Book one. ABC network committed to a book two (22 episodes). Book two brought  Rudy. Tom's son Wesley (Gregg Henry) and Julie's son Billy (James Carroll Jordan) into a second Generation story. The problem with book two is plot lines seem weaker than the original and far better mini-series. There are a few storylines that drives this story to the wrapped up tight ending. Strauss tries to topline this second volume of Rich Man like father-like figure, it works some levels and fails on others  at the same time. Book two comes off like an evening soap opera, but it does work if you think of it like that.To unearth this classic mini-series and TV sequel to DVD after 35 years of being in the vault. it shows very little age. The Master recordings are very clean for a 1970's production.  It is a great piece of TV to watch again and own for your libraryBennet PomerantzAUDIOWORLD
Title: Rich Man, Poor Man: Book 1

reviewText: This is the best miniseries I've ever seen. It has always been my favorite. Two brothers, one ambitious and the other a rebel. How their lives take them thru diverse paths and how they end up is an excellent example of life's ever changing road. The story line is interesting and the charactors are very real. The first time I saw this on TV, I was hooked and didn't miss a single episode. And every time they re-aired it, I wouldn't miss it. I originally bought it on VHS and now on DVD. It's a movie I never tire of watching. I highly recommend it.

reviewText: One of the most dramatic/ prolific mini-series ever created on television is "Rich Man, Poor Man". This brilliant production actually was produced and broadcasted before "Roots". As a child I watched "Rich Man, Poor Man" with my family every week with great anticipation. The seperate individual lives of Rudy and Tom were all people would talk about during the run of this show back in 1976. This is the show which turned Peter Straus and Nick Nolte into household names. And similar to "Roots", this series featured a multitude of many familiar faces. Actors like Robert Reed, Ed Asner, Norman Fell, Susan Blakely, Bill Bixby, Van Johnson, Ray Milland, Talia Shire, Kim Darby, just to name a few. I'll also never forget this show featuring one of the greatest fictional villians ever created. That would be Will Smith as Tom's mortal foe, Falconetti. Up until recently I had thought the name was spelled out in two words, "Falcon Eddie". (*that's what happens when you don't read the book*) As a kid this guy made me nervous. Now as an adult, he still makes my skin crawl. Truly one of the most dispicable characters ever created. Anyway, I've had this series on a crappy VHS for years. I have been waiting "YEARS" for this classic show to come on dvd. And as an added bonus, if I understand this correctly, will also include the sequel, Book 2. Now not near as great as the original, still an interesting continuation of the story. I haven't seen Book 2 since it's original broadcast. So this is an added treat for me. Anyway, for anyone who has yet to see this for the first time, I envy you. For those of you who are the fan that I am, all I can say is, "FINALLY"!!!
Title: Rich Man, Poor Man: Book 1

reviewText: This mini serial of 9 discs lasting over 27 hours shook me to the core. It was impossible to switch it off and I saw them all within 5 days. I got so totally involved and gripped as the story unfolds over 3 generations and still can't get it out of my mind. No words can justify Peter Strauss' emotional rendition of his role without over playing it in any way. I have since re-played the last disc many times as the ending is quite shattering.'Rich Man, Poor Man' ranks amongst my most treasured collection. It is pure gold and highly recommended.Deepak Singh

reviewText: This miniseries is probably my top miniseries.  I have the R2 DVD sets but will buy this release without hesitation if Universal supplied remastered prints to A/E for the release of both books.  The R2 Book 1 transfer quality was sub-par so I'm hoping we'll receive remastered transfers for the R1 release.  A/E has a good track record with their releaes, among the ones that I own in my collecion.Other reviewers have provided excellent summaries for this miniseries in other posted reviews here.  I've always thought that Nick Nolte set his acting bar so high here that it was difficult for him to surpass his performance in this show.  The other performers were perfectly cast in this one, Peter Strauss, Ed Asner, Steve Allen, Ray Milland, Bill Bixby, Dorothy McGuire, Dorothy Malone....on and on.This miniseries, to me, represented the beginning of the golden age of network miniseries productions, which continued into the 80's and beyond.

reviewText: The 70s was the era of the TV miniseries and I thought that Roots and Rich Man Poor Man had been the epitome. I own Roots (hard to watch, but still brilliant after all these years) and for the past year, I'd been looking for Rich Man Poor Man every few months. When it became available, I was excited because I was a child when this was originally broadcast and was not really allowed to watch it as I had been Roots. I remember how much my mother loved it, Peter Strauss, and then Nick Nolte. One surprise was that Susan Blakley was not as bad as I remember everyone saying she was, even with her frightening, distracting teeth and jaw flexing. Bill Bixby was also quite good and smarmy, and went on to direct a few episodes. The series itself? DEPRESSING! Every single situation is a set up for some DISASTER or another. There are NO HAPPY ENDINGS here, only pleasant interludes, but as I say, those are just the set ups: Rudy goes to college but he has no money; his evil father decides to lend him the money to start his own business, but has to use it to get the screw up brother out of a jam that doesn't even turn out to be true; you think that after the father is gone, the mother is going to get some relief and be happy, but you get to see what an insufferable bitch she either really always was, or became as a result of the years of emotional abuse she suffered at her husband's bread-baking hands; Rudy reunites with the love of his life whom he let get away because he was such a goody-two-shoes, he wouldn't sleep with her in high school, but they make each other so miserable, they can't be friends until they divorce; every time the Nolte character is about to get a break, he tries to control himself but the explodes, messing things up, even if he's in the right--and then years later, his son does the exact same thing...Oh god! and worse yet, nobody learns any lessons what-so-ever!!! Who the hell wants to watch 9 disks of that? What a huge disappointment and there's 2 weeks I'll never get back. I agree with those who said that "Book One" w/Nolte was way better than "Book Two," which was carried by the brilliant Susan Sullivan, because Rudy whose supposed to be handsome, popular and powerful, turns out to be pigheaded, more violent than his brother (who had actually been beaten by the father and became a boxer), and ultimately, impotent. The best part about the whole thing was the copious lack of breast implants. It's nice to see that at some point in American history, people didn't all look alike (with big immovable plastic body parts, frozen foreheads and lips that god didn't mean for white people to have or he would have made them that way--see Sylvester Stallone in the Expendables, another disaster!). Even when the bad guy FINALLY GETS IT, there is no satisfaction because he nearly takes everyone with him. And yes, I doubt there has ever been a more oily, better looking, creepy-goofy, murderous, jail-house rapist bad guy than Willie Smith's Falconetti (who looked like Jack Palance). You just keep hoping he gets it but his mindless malice is manic, energizer bunny-powered and you know you're going to have to look at him in yet another episode, wishing you could go through the screen and back 35 years to do it yourself. Willie did a really great job at creating a character so totally un-self aware, delusional, making himself the victim as he attacked one person after another over some perceived slight of his own making. And speaking of 9 disks, if a few of the panoramas, thoughtful pauses, bad face acting and scenes between Kate and Rudy (best described as EXCRUTIATING) where she calls him "senator" each and every time, were edited, it would have been at least a disk shorter. My husband stopped watching the first disk into book two and asked that I not watch it at all when he was at home. Damn!P.S. Keep your eyes peeled for all the Bobby Kennedy political references beginning with "Senator from NY." And we know how that ended.
Title: Rich Man, Poor Man: Book 1

reviewText: Oh, how time has flown by.  When you watch Nick Nolte in "Rich Man, Poor Man", it really makes you realize how long it has been since this wonderful mini series first debuted on TV--1976! Over 30 years ago! I was 12 at the time and I still fondly remember the show.  What a great cast RMPM has: Mr. Nolte (blond and gorgeous and oh so young), Peter Strauss (handsome as the uptight rich brother), Susan Blakely (what a terrific actress she was--haven't seen her in years), Ed Asner (who won an Emmy for his portrayal of Axel Jordache--a character radically different from Lou Grant), the late Bill Bixby (playing the pathetic Willie), Robert Reed (who proved he could play someone other than Mike Brady--he eats up the scenery in a delicious role) and Kim Darby (she's a hoot as the scheming psychotic Virginia Calderwood).  The scene where Virginia pounds on Rudy Jordache's mansion screaming his name has stuck in my mind all these years.  And the heartbreaking ending is still so sad to watch.  I forgot to mention the beautiful Kay Lenz, who ends up marrying Nick Nolte in the final episode.  She's a delight (another great actress who has disappeared).  Unfortunately, the mini series is not available in the United States for some mysterious reason, but you can buy a Region 2 PAL DVD.  If you have fond memories of this show--as I do--get yourself a Multiregion DVD player so you can relive this wonderful mini series.  And "Rich Man, Poor Man Book 2" was just released overseas in the last few weeks--I can't wait to begin watching it!
summary: One of the best mini series ever!
Title: Rich Man, Poor Man: Book 1

reviewText: This is one of the first miniseries I have purchased, then after seeing Peter Strauss, I had to have more of his DVD's.  He is an extremely fine actor. I am waiting on one more that I ordered.  The best part is, I do not get out of the home, I am a homebound WWII lady veteran with a handicapped daughter, so I get my entertainment on just watching my favorites.One cannot go wrong with all those I have purchased.  They arrive in new condition, and I buy the brand new if you have them, and be sure and get those to be played on the recorders that are for US, not another country.  Read all and buy right!  I have!  Thanks to Amazon, I will be a regular on purchasing the best, then when I get the Bluray, I will buy for that.  Merry Christmas Amazon!  I will treat myself!

reviewText: I bought this boxed set DVD of Rich man poor man a few months ago. I used to watch it every week in the 1970's. Never missed a week. It has v ery good acting from Nick Nolte, Peter Strauss, Susan Blakeley, Dorothy McGuire and Ed Asner who plays a serious part quite different from Mary Tyler Moore show. The story is great and keeps you interested all the way through. My one disappointment was the movie had no subtitles.  I am a bit hard of hearing and missed some words at times.But since I waited so long to get the DVD, I had to do with what I got.To be fair, Amazon.com did not state whether the movie had subtitles or not in the listing, but on the other hand they did not state it didn't.In this day and age, most DVD movies provide subtitles, so I presumed the movie did too -Wrong. I think Amazon should state either NO subtitles or has subtitles so people who need subtitles can decide if they want to buy the DVD. I can say, the movie is very good and I highly recommend it. To Canadians- buy the movie at amazon.com.Its twice the price on amazon.ca which is not surprising-ripoff.
Title: Rich Man, Poor Man: Book 1

reviewText: I met Peter Strauss for the first time after a staged reading at the Westport Playhouse, in which he, along with several other wonderful actors, gave a superb reading of a new play.  Speaking to him, briefly, afterwards, I mentioned the absence of "Rich Man" on DVD - and he agreed. He told me he is asked this a lot and does not understand why a terrific DVD edition of this classic miniseries is not available.  My God, it should be!  This was one of the first real TV "events" - must see TV before it really existed - with a superb, involving story of two brothers growing up in turbulent times, their lives and loves, and their ultimate search for happiness. The acting could not be better. Peter Strauss has always been an underrated actor, in my opinion.  In "The Jericho Mile" he gives a landmark performance.  Here, in "Rich Man," he believably ages from a high school student to an older, forlorn Senator trying to reclaim his humanity. It was an honor to speak to Mr. Strauss, who could not have been more gracious.  He was eager to see this miniseries on DVD and was also interested in being part of an "extras" package to boot. Can you imagine getting Mr. Strauss and Nick Nolte back to discuss the legendary film that began both their careers?  EVERY actor here gives a unique performance.  It was one of the unforgettable TV miniseries.  It deserves a gold star treatment!UPDATE on DVD release! "Rich Man, Poor Man" is a five star production, but the DVD release rates barely A STAR AND A HALF - it is almost a travesty.  I would like to commend Mr. Strauss, brilliant in the role in both series, for offering an excellent, perceptive, and interesting one hour long commentary track to accompany the first hour of the original series - but that is the ONLY recommendation I can give to this product.First, the video transfer is poor - there is NO high definition upgrade to the original show at all, so it looks like a typical TV show from the '70's, no upgrades at all. The sound quality is also poor.Second, and most important, the DVD has been EDITED!  Incredibly enough, there are whole scenes missing from the DVD - most grievously, in the final hour of the show, after Rudy nearly loses his career after hurting a college girl, whose photo club had taken nude pictures of a drunken Julie, there is a MISSING SCENE when we see the Van Johnson character return to tell Rudy that his political career can be saved - which leads directly back to the scenes where Julie begins to drink again and, inadvertently, causes a tragedy. The scene is gone! And parts of other scenes, including the introductions to the openings, also appear to be trimmed.I bought some foreign copies of both series some time ago - and both were better than this product. Make no mistake - A & E did this on the cheap and ended up leaving a tarnished legacy for a landmark series. It is STILL worth watching, for all the wonderful stories it tells, but this DVD product is a disgrace - and you will have to find another DVD or VHS tape to actually see the WHOLE series. The VHS tapes actually seem to have better sound and picture quality and more beautifully packaged as well. I would stick with them, except that Book Two, which has great moments, is not available on VHS tapes, but only on foreign DVD's, which, I'm sure, are of better quality than this disgrace. At least these shows don't appear to be edited.Too bad. Again, Mr. Strauss's commentaries are worth hearing, but I wish there was more. That's the ONLY extra for the high price you are paying.  Such a disappointment. Wasn't there ANYONE of any knowledge working for A & E who could have overseen this transfer? For the price you are paying, you deserve better.
summary: One of the All-Time GREAT TV Miniseries
Title: Rich Man, Poor Man: Book 1

reviewText: Though I haven't had time to watch these and bring back all those memories, I received the item in wonderful condition.
Title: Rich Man, Poor Man: Book 1

reviewText: What can be said of Rich Man Poor Man other than being one of the true epics of television. Peter Strauss and Nick Nolte are masterful in the roles as brothers. The series deserves to be watched by anyone who enjoys what television used to deliver.If there were 10 stars I would award accordingly.
Title: Rich Man, Poor Man: Book 1

reviewText: "Rich Man,Poor Man"was an excellent series that brought many great stars to the television audience of the 70's.Many of these stars went on to future films that made them icons in the film industry.I have it uncut in mint condition on VHS as I recorded it back when it premiered on "ABC's Movie of The Week" series.A second series came out shortly after called "Rich Man,Poor Man Book 2".It rounded out the first book nicely.But another film that Peter Strauss made,that was a film that never made it to video,and was excellent.It told of one of the Kennedy's that I never heard about before.Lt.Joseph Kennedy Jr.,a young pilot and valuable officer of World War 2,who died in a suicide mission,where he volunteered to crash a plane loaded with explosives into a German factory,that was a key target to our forces and the allies.He didn't follow the path of his famous brothers,but rather chose to follow his own path.His father shunned him because he wanted nothing to do with politics.A sad ending for such a promising young life,to die in battle.It was nonetheless a great film,that Strauss played very well.It's not in his list of films,and it should be.If it comes to video,I will buy it,and highly recommend it to others who like great films.The film is titled "Young Joe,The Forgotten Kennedy",made around 1977.
Title: Rich Man, Poor Man: Book 1

reviewText: I would have to rate this as the best mini-series ever produced. I recently got to see it again after about 25 years. I borrowed it from the library, which seems like the only place that still might have a copy. I recall when it was first on TV, I think it was an ABC Movie Event. Sitting each week enthralled in the storyline and then waiting for the next episode. This was the most thrilling thing to ever have been on television and it has stayed with me all these years. I became a life long Nick Nolte fan after seeing 'Rich Man, Poor Man'. I only wish this was on DVD! With all the junk that is put on DVD, why not something this ground breaking???
Title: Rich Man, Poor Man: Book 1

reviewText: I consider this series to be one of the classics that you should always have around because its hard to find anything today that isn't filled with sex.  This series was done at a time when you actually got the correct ratings and didn't get any surprises. I will be using Amazon from now on and the delivery process was so fast.  I would definitely and has already recommended it to my family, friends and co-workers.

reviewText: It's been a very long time since I saw this movie of course, but it's still a great story of a family's trials and tribulations.You will find yourself rooting for both Rudy and Tom for different reasons.Likewise you will find yourself hating their father played brilliantly by Ed Asner.  I never thought of Ed Asner as anything but a comedian truthfully, but this movie certainly makes you change your mind.The entire ensemble cast is superb in their respective parts.I found the ending to be extremely sad and found myself mentally re-writing the ending to suit what I would have liked to happen instead of the ending that was written.

reviewText: This was fantastic.  I had seen it years ago on TV and had looked for the series to come out on DVD.  I keep wondering how things would have turned out if the sons had been treated fairly during their growing up years.  It showed that everyone had their ups and downs and  they tried to deal.  Some dealt well and others not so well.  No matter how high you were on the social scale didn't mean happiness.  Just when things were looking up they were cut down again.  A must see for everyone.

reviewText: My RMPM arrived several days ago.  I have watched 3 episodes so far, and I am thrilled that I made this purchase. Although I admit that I originally had second-thoughts about the price before deciding to pull the "buy" trigger several months ago (plus I don't know anything about RMPM 2 and had to hope it doesn't turn out to be a price-inflating dog), the opportunity to own RMPM 1 was just too much to pass up. Fortunately, by the time it shipped Amazon's pre-order price guarantee had brought my copy down to $35, more than well-worth it in my opinion.The story is epic and superbly told.  Audio/video, so far, equally superb. Heck, they could even have stuck in the original commercials (or, to make additional revenue, maybe even current commercials, I suppose) - being a TV mini-series, the commercial breaks are obvious and I half-way expected a real commercial to come on when they occurred, that's how good the remastered quality is - you feel like you're watching a current show.If you love well-done and well-acted mini-series with a well-told storyline, whether or not you have seen RMPM before, you won't regret buying this one.  I CANNOT say well-acted enough to do RMPM justice! As others have noted, it made Nick Nolte a star.  I don't know if Peter Strauss was unknown or not before RMPM, but he was certainly better known after it. The other performances cannot be beat either, plus you will never meet a better-portrayed bad guy than Falconetti. It is the Nick Nolte-Falconetti storyline that is the most memorable for me. You will have your own favorite portion of the story to remember.As for Robert Reed's missing "willy" and backside that seems to concern a couple of other reviewers about possible editing, it is possible that RMPM was originally aired in two versions, one for the American audience and one for the more nudity-tolerant European TV audience. That could be why Region 2 shows the backside and Region 1 doesn't. I don't know if that's the case, just speculating so because one reviewer says his Region 2 sports a bare-bottomed Reed. Be that as it may, I'm perfectly happy with my American version.
summary: A purchase you will not regret
Title: Rich Man, Poor Man: Book 1

reviewText: Out of nostalgia, I recently borrowed this DVD set from the library. I'd seen both series (books I and II) back in the '70's and was curious to see if they held up.What had always stuck in my head from past viewings of this miniseries was Nick Nolte's performance as Tom Jordache, and that, still, makes this DVD worth watching.  Nolte does occasionally slide into a Southern-flavored accent, for no discernable reason. Maybe it was Nolte's way of conveying Tom's working-class demeanor. But when it happens, it sticks out like a sore thumb.  Aside from that oddity, his performance is excellent.  Nolte is able to strike a balance between Tom's "loner" or outsider status and his inner tenderness, with great results.  He's especially moving in two deathbed scenes.Peter Strauss nicely conveys most of Rudy's characteristics from Shaw's novel, and makes him probably a more sympathetic character than he is in the book.  I never thought much of the actress Susan Blakely, and her performance as Julie, Rudy's true love, is nothing special.  It's a tribute to Strauss and Nolte that I couldn't picture their parts being played by any other actors, but Blakely brings nothing to her performance that any other reasonably accomplished 1970's actress wouldn't have given.  Blythe Danner, Madeline Stowe or Jenny Agutter (if she could have done an American accent) might really have brought something to Julie that Susan Blakely couldn't.Supporting performances vary - Ed Asner and Dorothy McGuire are very good as Axel and Mary Jordache, but Robert Reed's performance as Teddy Boylan, with his odd take on a British-like accent, is very stiff.  But it serves its purpose.  Bill Bixby is charming and ultimately pathetic as Willie Abbott.  Talia Shire is good as Tom's slutty first wife, but Kay Lenz as Kate is pretty bad.  She doesn't bring any earthiness or sensibility to the part of Tom's last love (at least, as per her character in the novel) - just a kind of surfer-girl shallowness.Two of the biggest disappointments for me regarding "Rich Man, Poor Man Book I" are:  first, the washed-out colors of the video transfer.  This is particularly noticable in long shots and outdoor scenes.  Second, is the casual approach taken by the producers in creating authentic 1945-1965 time period(s) with the right costumes and hairstyles.  There's lip service to the 1940's in the first two episodes (and that's not consistent), but after that, it's pretty much still mostly 1970's in terms of costumes, hair & makeup, aside from a bouffant hairdo sported by Susan Blakely in some early 1960's scenes.  These inaccuracies didn't annoy me as a kid watching this back in the '70's but they annoy me now.I consider "Book II" a waste of time.  It's a feast of embarrassingly bad acting; abrupt scene changes; poor dialogue; boring plot lines, and is even more slipshod in terms of recreating an authentic late 1960's-period hair and costumes, than Book I was in creating the 1945-1965 era.  Plus, it was a total cash-in attempt to ride the coattails of Rich Man, Poor Man's success, without good source material (which Book I has, thanks to Irwin Shaw's novel).  Nolte was right to refuse to appear in it.All that being said:  Would I buy or rent this?  Rent only, and for "Book I" only.  That's a good story based on a good novel, and is still engaging (despite some deadish/soap-opera moments, mostly in the Rudy-Julie relationship) and upheld by a fine performance from Nick Nolte.
summary: Rent it for the first installment; skip the second
Title: Rich Man, Poor Man: Book 1

reviewText: Ever since the advent of DVD people have been hopeful that someday "Rich Man, Poor Man" would makes it way to the home DVD market. Well, the wait is finally over: on September, 28, 2010 "Rich Man, Poor Man" makes its debut on DVD, not only for the fans who remember watching the min-series on television back in the seventies, but for a whole new generation of viewers who can enjoy the series for posterity.It was actually Fred Silverman, the then president of ABC, who green lit "Rich Man, Poor Man", TV's first min-series (many give that claim to "Roots", but "Rich Man, Poor Man" aired in February 1976, a full year before "Roots"). The series (based on the 1970 Irwin Allen novel) originally aired every Tuesday night, for a total of 12 consequetive episodes before culminating with its finale, a first for this type of programming. The show was both a critical and ratings smash, and executives quickly ordered "Rich Man, Poor Man-Book 2" for the fall of 1976. "Rich Man..." dealt with the German immigrant family named Jordache and the bulk of the series dramatized the lives of the two Jordache brothers Rudy and Tom. Both were polar opposites: Rudy was intelligent, college educated, and an entrepreneur, where as Tom was defiant and the rebel who turned to boxing to support himself. Julie was the girl with whom Rudy fell in love with."Rich Man, Poor Man" was pure soap opera, and was a forerunner to the big primetime serials of the 1980's, showing TV executives that not only would viewers follow a continuous story during the daytime hours, but also during the evening. "Rich Man..." garnered several Emmy awards, including wins for its music (the opening theme, composed by Alex North, is still one of the most haunting themes in history), direction, and one for acting. The ensemble cast included Peter Strauss and Nick Nolte (in his first starring role) as the Jordache brothers Rudy and Tom, and Susan Blakely as Julie. Others in the cast included George Maharis, Van Johnson, Dorothy McGuire, Ed Asner (who received an Emmy), Robert Redd, and Dick Sargent.This set includes all episodes from both the original "Rich Man, Poor Man" and its sequel and it comes on 9 dics. Bonuses include informative commentary with Peter Strauss and television historian David Bianculli.
summary: "Now This Is An Original And A Classic!"
Title: Rich Man, Poor Man: Book 1

reviewText: "Rich Man, Poor Man: The Complete Collection" is a nine-disc collector's set containing all 34 remastered episodes from Books I and II of the classic 1970's series based on Irwin Shaw's best-selling novel.  The series, which won four Emmy Awards and received 22 nominations, stars Peter Strauss, Nick Nolte, Ed Asner, Bill Bixby, Susan Blakely, and Robert Reed, and focuses on the period of tremendous social and political change immediately after World War II through the early 1960's.Rudy Jordache (Strauss) and his troubled brother, Tom (Nolte), follow divergent paths away from their impoverished immigrant upbringing.  While ambitious Rudy seems destined for success, Tom suffers from an endless streak of bad luck.  Nolte went on to big-screen stardom after undertaking the showy role of Tom.  Asner, known for his role as Lou Grant on "The Mary Tyler Moore Show" (which was airing originally during the broadcast of "Rich Man, Poor Man"), is excellent as the family patriarch.  Supporting players include Ray Milland, Kim Darby, Dorothy Maguire, Van Johnson, George Maharis, Talia Shire, and Norman Fell.The only bonus extra is audio commentary for Book I: Chapter 1 featuring Peter Strauss.
summary: One of the Best TV Mini Series

reviewText: Grew up watching this series and actually had owned it previously on VHS. The series is an excellent adaptation of Shaw's book (which I'd read as well), so I was sad to see that the transfer to DVD looked like I'd copied it from my VHS tape (and not very well). The majority of the scenes are faded and look like they came from a copy that had been watched too many times, yet occasionally the screen will clear and it looks like it was ACTUALLY on DVD (these are few and far between).That aside, still worth watching and at the price worth owning.
Title: Rich Man, Poor Man: Book 1

reviewText: Book One is somewhat more compelling with both major characters involved in the plot.  Book Two lacks something due to the departure of one of those characters and the long, dragged-out Senate hearings. But the series as a whole is very strong, with mostly good acting, decent music, and an interesting story featuring dozens of characters over the decades from the 1940s to late 1960s.
Title: Rich Man, Poor Man: Book 1

reviewText: Through the seller "Rightaway today" I received a six disc DVD set and was not at all disappointed with the quality. Probably bad timing though as I think it's now officially released a lot cheaper. The forerunner of all TV mini series it still holds up as the best ever produced. Nick Nolte as Tom could not have been better cast. I don't know what he is really like but it was as if he wasn't acting as his character was so convincing. Ed Azner played the kind of powerful support role like Burl Ives did in "A Big Country" and "Cat on a Hot Tin Roof"Unlike so many other mini series, the story line has some depth and sends us a question of what success and happiness are all about. I also picked up before seeing it on someone else's reveiw,the blooper in filming the World Trade Center. That was built in 1973 well after the time frame of the story. This series I fully recommend as a definate collectors item.
Title: Rich Man, Poor Man: Book 1

reviewText: I preordered this DVD set because I read this book several times over and really loved it. The storyline was superb, oh, I forgot, I was talking about the book, not the movie. After receiving the DVD set, I promptly fed it in my trusty DVD player and guess what? It's not even closed captioned or subtitled! My wife and I are deaf. Without closed captioning or subtitles, it will not benefit us at all. I immediately returned this movie to Amazon and yes, Amazon did a great job refunding me our hard earned dollars. The distributor, A&E; blatantly ignored the deaf masses. This is discrimination! I have e-mailed to A&E; once before in September, in November and today concerning this DVD expressing my outrage. Guess what? They never replied. Until A & E finally have this DVD in closed captioning or subtitles, I urge you kind consumers, DO NOT BUY THIS DVD SET!! And show your support for the Deaf community!Rich Man, Poor Man: The Complete Collection
Title: Rich Man, Poor Man: Book 1

reviewText: I've been waiting for this to be released since the early 1980's.  After so many years of waiting I gave up then missed it's release on VHS years ago.  I just found out it was released on DVD last year.  Amazon is terrible about notifying when an item is released after signing up to be notified for unavailable items.  I've done it many times then find it in stores before I ever get notification which is why I keep missing videos I'm interested in.I agree that there appears to be some scenes missing that I remember from the first run back in the 1970's when it first aired.  There was a scene where something was edited out or could have been a bad cut, but the dialog suggested it was an expletive.  There's a scene in Book One where Rudy and Julie are talking at home then the next scene she's in the hospital.  I couldn't figure out if I missed something or if there was a serious cut.  I assumed she was in the hospital for alcoholism, but it wasn't obvious.  Fade ins and outs were edited where coming back from where a commercial would have been, it appears to jump into a scene as if the beginning of the scene was edited.  Running times are not even close on some episodes.  The last chapter for Book One was short about fifteen minutes.I'm thinking that the print A&E; received might not have been the best copy either so we're lucky to have anything at all.  Still, anything is better than the chopped up versions I've seen many years ago in reruns.Overall, I thought the quality was better than what we had seen back in it's day and I'm thankful it finally came out.  I didn't have a problem with the sound and it looked pretty good on my HD TV in comparison to the color TV back then.  I've seen worse picture quality on other DVDs, but I didn't have an overall problem with this one.  Some scenes were a little dark or grainy, but I figured whatever print A&E; used had probably deteriorated over the years.For the price, it's very reasonable to be able to see this again.  I also think it's great that Book Two was also included especially for the low Amazon price.  I wish there had been more commentary from Peter Strauss besides the first hour.  Maybe if they hadn't waited so long to release this they could have gotten interviews or commentaries from some of the stars before they passed away.  It's still worth getting because this mini-series hasn't been on the air in over twenty years.  The last time I saw it was in the 1980's and every two minutes they would break for commericals.  It was so frustrating to watch I gave up.
summary: It's About Time This Was Released on DVD
Title: Rich Man, Poor Man: Book 1
